gold_sents: A paraplegic individual who uses a wheelchair sued Chipotle for violations of the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) and California state law in two of its California restaurants.[SENTMARKER]The defendant implemented a new "Customers with Disabilities" which the district court found to be in compliance with the ADA, but the Ninth Circuit found otherwise, that viewing the ingredients behind the counter was part of the "Chipotle Experience."[SENTMARKER]Ultimately, the defendant lowered the heights of the walls in front of the food-preparation areas in all of its California locations so that customers in wheelchairs could see the ingredients, and the plaintiff was awarded $898,549 in attorneys' fees and costs and $5,000 in statutory damages.

pegasus_output_sents: On May 30, 1997, a group of disabled concert-goers filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the district of Colorado against the owners and operators of Fiddler's Green, Inc., a concert venue in Denver, Colorado.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Colorado Anti-Discrimination Act by failing to provide appropriate wheelchair and companion seating for persons who use wheelchairs or other mobility aids and their companions in violation of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the plaintiffs purchased tickets to a Tina Turner concert and discovered that the front section of wheelchair seating was occupied by machinery and persons operating the machinery and thus, there was no available seating for them in that section.[SENTMARKER]The complaint further alleged that defendants continued to advertise and/or claim that they sell tickets for wheelchair seating in the reserved seating section and that they offer a "Premier Ticket Program" for nondisabled concertgoers.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the court entered an injunction requiring the defendants to comply with the ADA and the CETA.

gold_sents: On December 2, 2020, the U.S. Department of Justice filed a complaint against the National Railroad Passenger Corporation (“Amtrak”) for allegedly violating the Americans with Disabilities Act, 42 U.S.C. §§ 12131-12165, by failing to make its intercity rail stations accessible to individuals with disabilities by July 26, 2020, as required by the Act.[SENTMARKER]The case was never properly docketed or assigned to a judge, however, because the government announced its settlement with Amtrak on the same day.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required Amtrak to design at least 135 accessible stations, complete construction at 90 stations, and be in the process of constructing at least 45 stations within 10 years of the settlement date.[SENTMARKER]The agreement also required Amtrak to train staff on ADA compliance, establish a monitor-approved process for managing ADA complaints, and create a settlement fund to compensate individuals who were harmed by Amtrak’s most inaccessible stations.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was monitored by the Federal Railroad Administration and the Department of Justice.

pegasus_output_sents: In March 2016, ten students with disabilities sued the Orleans Parish School Board, the Louisiana Department of Education, and the Louisiana Board of Education (BESE) in the U.S. District Court for the New Orleans Eastern District for violating the Americans with Disabilities Education Act (ADA) by failing to implement policies, procedures, and practices related to school discipline that protect these students' federal procedural safeguards and shield them from discrimination on the basis of their disability.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory, preliminary, and permanent injunctive relief requiring the defendants to cease their unlawful policies, practices, customs, patterns, and/or practices that deprive plaintiffs and all similarly situated children with disabilities their statutory rights to receive a free appropriate public education and to be free from discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in March 2016.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the defendants would disseminate required policy guidance to each school under its jurisdiction annually by March 1 for the duration of this agreement.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to provide annual professional development to all school staff and to develop and disseminate information to parents about the prohibited practice of undocumented suspensions.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was subject to court approval.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On June 20, 2016, the Louisiana Department of Education (LDE) was sued in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern district of Louisiana for failing to investigate the exclusion of students with disabilities at a charter school.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the LDE failed to identify and evaluate potentially disabled children and failed to provide appropriate education placements, services, and accommodations on the behalf of those children.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a consent judgment in the case, which was finalized on June 20, 2016.[SENTMARKER]The consent judgment required the LDOE to identify, evaluate, implement, and provide appropriate accommodations for all children with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The LDE also required each NOLA Type 2 and Type 5 Charter LEA to complete the draft "PB v White – Special Education Program Description template" by January 29, 2016.

gold_sents: Several student members of a high school religious club brought suit against the city of said high school alleging violation of their freedom of speech, assembly, and free exercise of religion under the First Amendment's Establishment Clause and Free Exercise Clause.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged unlawful discrimination based on the religious content of their speech in violation of the Equal Access Act and the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause, in addition to violation of their freedom of expression under Massachusetts state law.[SENTMARKER]On June 16, 2003, the Court entered a consent decree between the school and the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]As per the decree, the defendants agreed to rescind punishment of the plaintiffs for the distribution of the religious materials, remove prior restraints and content-based restrictions of distribution of materials during non-instructional time without complying with substantive and procedural safeguards, so long as distribution doesn't substantially and materially disrupt the operation of the school or the new policies.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were awarded $28,500 in attorneys' fees and costs and the case was closed.
pegasus_output_sents: [ENTITYCHAIN] March 2003 DATE | Westfield Public Schools ORG | District of Massachusetts DATE | United States District Court DATE ||| Christian Liberty Counsel DATE | Christian Liberty Law Center DATE | Plaintiff's attorney's fees and costs .<n>On March 3, 2003, a Christian Liberty lawyer filed a lawsuit against the Westfield Public School District in the U.S. District Court for the district of Massachusetts on behalf of a group of Christian high school students.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the school district had violated the First Amendment rights of Christian students by prohibiting them from distributing candy canes with Bible verses and other religious material.[SENTMARKER]The school district denied the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case was settled on May 5, 2003.

gold_sents: On May 31, 2018, The National Federation of the Blind filed this lawsuit in the U.C.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the District of Maryland (Northern Division).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued the U.S. Department of Education and the Secretary of Education along with the Acting Assistant Secretary, claiming that the changes to the 2018 OCR Manual violated the Administrative Procedure Act, 5 U.S.C. §§ 551 et seq., and was contrary to the mission of the OCR.[SENTMARKER]These changes in § 108(t) of the 2018 OCR Manual require mandatory dismissal of complaints if the claim is either part of "a pattern" of complaints against multiple recipients, or places an unreasonable burden on OCR's resources.[SENTMARKER]These changes also eliminate the appeal rights of complainants.[SENTMARKER]The parties came to a settlement agreement reopening complaints dismissed under the contested rules of the manual and allowing parties that had their cases dismissed under the rule to petition the Department to reopen their cases.[SENTMARKER]The case is not officially closed until February 2021, when the parties can no longer file for further enforcement.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 31, 2018, the NAACP and its state and local units filed this suit against the Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights (OCR) alleging that the March 2018 Manual, which superseded the 2015 Manual and contained new provisions requiring mandatory dismissal of certain complaints and eliminating the right of complainants to appeal determinations by OCR, violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (APA) and Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (C.R.A.).[SENTMARKER]On November 19, 2018, the parties notified the Court that settlement negotiations had broken down and that OCR planned to release a revised OCR Case Processing Manual later that day, which could render Plaintiffs' requests for relief moot.[SENTMARKER]The next day, Plaintiffs sought leave to file an amended complaint and a Motion for a Preliminary Injunction to add allegations that Defendants were also using section 108(k) of the March 2018, Manual to dismiss complaints on the basis that a similar complaint filed by another individual had been previously dismissed pursuant to section108(t).[SENTMARKER]The Court granted Plaintiffs' motion to dismiss, and the parties agreed to provide the Court with an update on the status of the directed investigations pursuant to paragraphs 2 and 3 of the amended complaint.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: The National Federation of the Blind (NFB) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against the Department of Education (DOE) and the Office for Civil Rights (OCR) on May 31, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the DOE and OCR violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by mandating the handling and processing of complaints of illegal discrimination made to OCR for investigation.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, on March 5, 2018, the DOE issued a revised manual, which superseded the 2015 Manual and contained new provisions requiring mandatory dismissal of certain complaints and eliminating the right of complainants to appeal determinations by OCR to the Enforcement Office Director.[SENTMARKER]On May 31, 2018, the NFB filed the instant action, claiming that the changes violated the ADA and Chapter 5 of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on June 30, 2018.

gold_sents: On November 7, 2006, the people of Michigan approved by majority vote a statewide ballot initiative-Proposal 2-which amended the Michigan Constitution to prohibit discrimination or preferential treatment based on race or gender in the operation of public employment, public education or public contracting in the State.[SENTMARKER]Both Proposal 2 and the University of Michigan's announcement that it would comply triggered litigation.[SENTMARKER]On November 15, 2012, the en banc Sixth Circuit held that Proposal 2 created a comparative structural burden that undermined the Equal Protection Clause (which the court called the "political process" argument).[SENTMARKER]Accordingly, the court found Proposal 2 unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]On March 24, 2013, the Supreme Court granted review of the case.[SENTMARKER]Argument will be after the Court's summer break.[SENTMARKER]On October 15, 2013 the Supreme Court heard oral argument in the case.[SENTMARKER]In an opinion written by Justice Kennedy and joined by Justice Roberts and Justice Alito, the court reversed the Sixth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]There were two concurring opinions and a single dissent.[SENTMARKER]In his opinion Kennedy asserts that this is not a case about resolving the debate about racial preferences, but rather about whether it is constitutional for Michigan to allow its voters to decide the issue.[SENTMARKER]The court holds that there is no authority in the Federal Constitution or in this Court’s precedents for the Judiciary to set aside Michigan laws that commit to the voters the determination whether racial preferences may be considered in governmental decisions, in particular with respect to school admissions.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 8, 2006, a collection of interest groups and individuals, including the Coalition to Defend Affirmative Action, Integration and Immigration Rights, and Fight for Equality By Any Means Necessary, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan seeking a declaratory judgment that Proposal 2 was invalid and a permanent injunction against its enforcement.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the provisions of Proposal 2 affecting public colleges and universities violated the United States Constitution and federal statutory law.[SENTMARKER]In its March 18, 2008 Opinion and Order, the District Court granted the Attorney General's Motion for Summary Judgment and dismissed the Complaint on its merits.[SENTMARKER]The District Court also denied the Universities' Motion to Dismiss for misjoinder.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On January 1, 1997, El Paso converted its traditional defined benefit pension plan into a "cash balance" plan.[SENTMARKER]This means that older, longer-service employees actually receive no additional benefits for their years of employment with El Paso in 2002, 2003, 2004 and many subsequent years.[SENTMARKER]As a result of El Paso's transition method, employees who were over 50 on the date their company went to the cash benefit plan had on average a 91.5 percent reduction in benefits after five years, and still had a 77.0 percent reduction after 15 years.[SENTMARKER]Over 90 percent of damages were borne by older employees.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In December 2005, the FDIC conducted a compliance examination of the bank.[SENTMARKER]Based on information gathered in its examination, the FDIC determined that it had reason to believe that in 2004 the bank engaged in a pattern or practice of home-mortgage lending discrimination against black applicants, on the basis of race, in the pricing of conventional, first-lien refinance loans on owner-occupied, one-to-four family properties, in violation of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act, the Fair Housing Act, and their implementing regulations.[SENTMARKER]The FDIC referred the matter to the Attorney General for appropriate enforcement action, following its determination on October 23, 2006.[SENTMARKER]On November 18, 2009, this court entered the Agreed Order for Resolution.[SENTMARKER]The Bank agreed to pay a total of $3 million in disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and a civil penalty.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: In November 2011, two undocumented Mexican immigrants and three fair housing groups filed this class-action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Alabama against the State of Alabama.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that a state statute violated the Fair Housing Act and was preempted by federal immigration law because it required mobile home owners to pay for a government-issued registration while prohibiting undocumented residents from making payments to government officials.[SENTMARKER]Because the law made it illegal to possess a mobile home without registration and because it was illegal for undocumented residents to obtain the registration, the law effectively made such persons homeless.[SENTMARKER]The District Court (Judge Myron H. Thompson) enjoined the State from enforcing the law.[SENTMARKER]The State appealed, but the Eleventh Circuit rendered it moot because in May 2012 the Alabama legislature amended the statute to exclude mobile home registration.[SENTMARKER]The District Court dismissed the case in May 2014, upon stipulation of the parties.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 18, 2011, the plaintiffs filed this lawsuit against the defendants in the United States District Court, Alabama Middle District.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' enforcement of  30 of the Beason-Hammon Alabama taxpayer and citizen protection act, 2011 Ala.[SENTMARKER]Laws 535, in a manner which essentially prohibits individuals who cannot prove their citizenship status from remaining in their manufactured homes violated their civil rights.[SENTMARKER]The defendants sought a stay of enforcement pending the outcome of their appeal for the non-enjoined sections of the law.[SENTMARKER]The Eleventh Circuit granted in part and denied in part the stay.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on May 8, 2014.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On November 18, 2011, two Latino residents of Alabama filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Alabama against the State of Alabama, alleging that the state's new immigration laws violate the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Alabama's immigration laws are impermissibly restricting the privileges and immunities of the citizens of Alabama.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case.

gold_sents: This case resulted in the largest residential fair lending settlement in U.S. history, with $335 million being paid to compensate African-American and Hispanic borrowers who were allegedly charged more based on their race or national origin.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 21, 2011, the Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this civil rights lawsuit against Countrywide, acting through its various divisions and subsidiaries (collectively, "Countrywide"), alleging that Countrywide discriminated against more than 200,000 Hispanic and African-American borrowers in its residential mortgage lending.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleges that these borrowers were charged higher fees and interest rates because of their race or national origin, and not because of the borrowers’ creditworthiness or other objective criteria related to borrower risk.[SENTMARKER]The settlement provides $335 million in compensation for victims of Countrywide’s discrimination during a period when Countrywide originated millions of residential mortgage loans as one of the nation’s largest single-family mortgage lenders.[SENTMARKER]Countrywide currently operates as a subsidiary of Bank of America but does not originate new loans.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York today announced that Countrywide Financial Corporation has agreed to pay more than $2 million to settle allegations that it discriminated against African-American and Hispanic borrowers by steering them into subprime mortgage loans when non-Hispanic white borrowers with similar credit profiles received prime loans.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]Countrywide was one of the largest single-family mortgage lenders in the United States between 2004 and 2008 during the mortgage boom.

gold_sents: Low-income minority individuals in need of affordable housing filed a lawsuit under the Fair Housing Act, the Civil Rights Act of 1866, the Civil Rights Act of 1871, 42 U.S.C. § 1983, and the Civil Rights Act of 1964 against the Town of Smithtown, complaining that  Smithtown operated its voucher program with a residency preference that discriminated on the basis of race, color, and national origin.[SENTMARKER]The court entered an order and final judgment approving the parties' settlement agreement under which the Town of Smithtown agreed to implement an anti-discrimination educational program, to affirmatively market the Section 8 Program to minority persons, to inform the public of its non-discriminatory policies, to maintain and preserve records for purposes of recordkeeping and reporting, and to pay $925,000 to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]This settlement remains in effect until 2019.

pegasus_output_sents: On September 9, 2011, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (S.D.NY) filed this civil rights suit in the United States District Court in Manhattan against the developers and architect of The Larkspur, a residential apartment complex in Manhattan, New York.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the Fair Housing Act by failing to design and construct the apartment complex so as to be accessible to persons with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The defendants entered into a consent decree in 2012 to resolve the complaint.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered into by the court on September 26, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the following conditions: (i) the defendants would not discriminate in the design or construction of any apartment complex; .[SENTMARKER](ii) they would pay a civil penalty in the amount of $50,000; and (iii) the defendant would be required to develop a plan to ensure that all apartment units are accessible to all residents.

gold_sents: On May 12, 2005, individual New York residents and the New York ACORN local chapter filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Easter District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued Nassau County and the Village of Garden City under the Fair Housing Act, the Civil Rights Act of 1866, the Civil Rights Act of 1964, and the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs asked the court to enjoin the defendants from proceeding with discriminatory zoning practices; to order Garden City to approve a proposed zoning that would allow for affordable housing; and to order the defendants to take all actions necessary to assure that the Social Service Site be redeveloped to maximize the availability of affordable and integrated housing.[SENTMARKER]On February 15, 2012, Judge Arthur D. gold_sents: This 2011 federal fair lending lawsuit in the Western District of Texas was brought by the United States against a local bank the U.S. alleged had engaged in a pattern or practice of providing loans to Hispanics only at higher rates than to non-Hispanics, without justification.[SENTMARKER]In the settlement, submitted simultaneously with the complaint, the bank agreed to develop and establish uniform pricing policies and procedures designed to ensure nondiscriminatory pricing, and to numerous other implementation provisions, including fair credit training, systemic monitoring, complaint resolution processes, and $91,000 in damages to aggrieved persons.[SENTMARKER]The provisions of the order were scheduled to last 4 and 1/4 years.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 17, 2011, the United States of America filed this lawsuit in the Western district of Texas against Nixon State Bank, a Texas-based bank.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Nixon charged higher prices for loans on the basis of national origin, including charging higher rates of interest, in violation of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act (ECOA).[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that the bank failed to supervise or monitor the performance of its loan officers effectively to ensure compliance with fair lending laws.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the consent order, Nixon agreed to develop and establish uniform pricing policies and procedures to ensure that prices it charges for the loans covered by this Order, including the portion of the price that reflects the discretion of the loan officer or any company employee, are set in a non-discriminatory manner consistent with the requirements of ECOA.[SENTMARKER]Nixon also agreed to compensate its Hispanic borrowers of unsecured consumer loans.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On July 1, 2014, the United States of America filed this complaint against Nixon State Bank in the Western district of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Nixon had engaged in a pattern or practice of lending discrimination on the basis of national origin in the pricing of unsecured consumer loans in violation of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act (ECOA).[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged inconsistency in loan administration, inconsistent loan pricing, and inconsistency in following loan pricing.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent order in which Nixon agreed to develop and establish uniform pricing policies and procedures designed to ensure that the prices it charges for the loans covered by this order were set in a non-discriminatory manner consistent with the requirements of ECOA.[SENTMARKER]The consent order also required Nixon to compensate its Hispanic borrowers.

pegasus_output_sents: On January 11, 2011, the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this civil rights case in the District Court for the Northern district of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Defendant Home Mortgage, Inc., a Texas-based mortgage originator, discriminated against African-American borrowers by charging them higher prices than non-African American borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled on January 11, 2011 with the defendant agreeing to pay $35,500 in disgorgement, $22,000 in compensation, and to implement a monitoring program designed to prevent and detect fair lending violations.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: The U.S. Department of Justice charged Prime Lending, a wholly-owned subsidiary of PlainsCapital Bank, a bank chartered by the Texas Department of Banking and a member of the Federal Reserve System, with violating the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that PrimeLending discriminated on the basis of race against African-American borrowers by charging them higher or lower annual percentage rates of interest than the "par" interest rate at which they would originate the loan.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendant agreed to pay a total of $367,900.95 to settle the complaint.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was approved by the court on October 2, 2010.

gold_sents: On September 26, 2013, the United States of America filed a lawsuit in the Eastern District of Wisconsin against Southport Bank, under the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, represented by the Civil Rights Division of the Department of Justice, sought a declaratory judgment, injunctive relief, compensatory damages to all of the victims of the defendant's discriminatory policies, and a civil penalty, alleging that the defendant discriminated against African American and Hispanic borrowers because of race and national origin in its residential mortgage lending.[SENTMARKER]On October 11, 2013, the District Court (Judge Joseph Peter Stadtmueller) entered a consent order between the parties.[SENTMARKER]The defendant did not admit to any pattern or practice of discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The order enjoined the defendant from engaging in any act or practice that discriminates on the basis of race or national origin in any aspect of a residential real estate-related transaction in violation of the Fair Housing Act or any credit transaction in violation of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act. oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On September 26, 2013, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of Wisconsin filed this civil rights case against Southport Bank of Kenosha, Wisconsin in the United States District Court in the Eastern district of Wisconsin.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that from 2007 to 2008, Southport discriminated against African-American and Hispanic borrowers in its wholesale mortgage lending program by denying them the opportunity to qualify for a mortgage based on their race or national origin.[SENTMARKER]On October 11, 2013, the court entered an order enjoining Southport from engaging in any act or practice that discriminates on the basis of race, national origin, or in any aspect of a residential real estate-related transaction in violation of the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.[SENTMARKER]The court also ordered Southport to pay $687,000 in compensation to affected persons.[SENTMARKER]The case was handled by Jocelyn Samuels and Matthew Krueger.

gold_sents: Following an investigation by the United States Department of Justice, the U.S. filed this lawsuit against the State of Connecticut, its Department of Mental Retardation, and the Director of Southbury Training School (Southbury) on July 25, 1986, alleging that living conditions at Southbury placed residents in grave danger of bodily harm and death.[SENTMARKER]On the same day, the parties also entered into a consent decree that required Southbury to provide better programming, disciplinary procedures, medical care, recordkeeping, and increase staffing.[SENTMARKER]After some problems with compliance and placing the state in contempt, the Court assigned a special master to monitor Southbury.[SENTMARKER]After making significant progress, on March 25, 2006, the court ended judicial oversight, but retained jurisdiction over the consent decree and remedial plan.[SENTMARKER]On November 2, 2009, the Court granted a joint motion to dismiss the case because the parties agreed that the consent decree and remedial plan were fully implemented.

gold_sents: On June 8, 2015, civil detainees confined in the Tucson Sector of the U.S. Border Patrol filed a class action lawsuit, alleging violations of the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment and the APA due to inhumane and punitive conditions while they were detained in holding cells.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a PI mandating that defendants must maintain conditions of confinement adequate for the detainees' physical needs and provide detainees with mats and blankets after 12 hours.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit affirmed the PI order.[SENTMARKER]In 2018 the plaintiffs filed a motion for partial summary judgment on the issue of defendants' obligation to provide raised beds for detainees held for any period requiring sleep; the district court denied this motion.[SENTMARKER]After a 7-day trial in January 2020, the district court held that these extended confinement conditions violated the Constitution and issued an order enjoining the defendants from holding detainees for longer than 48 unless they provided conditions of confinement that meet basic human needs.[SENTMARKER]This permanent injunction was ordered and has been in effect since April 2020.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: This is a statewide class action brought on behalf of Florida residents who are Medicaid eligible adults with disabilities who are unnecessarily confined to a nursing facility that receives Medicaid funding.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs in this action are Medicaid-supported residents of nursing facilities who allege that they could reside and receive appropriate care in the community.[SENTMARKER]They further assert that defendant state officials have subjected them to unjustified discrimination on the basis of disability by failing to assess properly the services that would enable them to live in the Community, by not informing them about these services, and by not supporting these services generally.[SENTMARKER]On October 14, 2008, I granted the motion, certifying a class consisting of any Florida Medicaid-eligible adult who, at any time during the litigation, resided in a nursing home that received Medicaid funding, and who could and would have resided in thecommunity with appropriate community-based services.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the claims of the other named plaintiffs as moot, decertified the class, and made permanent the injunction in the plaintiff's favor.

pegasus_output_sents: On February 7, 2011, the Native Hawaiian Legal Corporation (NHLC) filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Hawaii on behalf of inmates at Saguaro Correctional Center and Red Rock Correctional Center.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their rights under the federal Constitution and the RLUIPA Id by preventing them from practicing their native Hawaiian religion.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case on the ground that the defendant was not doing business in the Southern District of Florida, and therefore, the venue requirements were not met.[SENTMARKER]On May 14, 2015, the court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment required the defendants to allow outdoor worship classes six times a year for 1.5 hours each time during regularly scheduled ritual class, allow the inmates to participate in two solstice/ox and two Makahiki celebrations each year, publish a communal items list in the prison chapel, and allow the inmate population to identify a source/equin for replacement.

pegasus_output_sents: Muslim prisoners filed this civil rights action in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern district of Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their First and Eighth Amendment rights by depriving them of adequate nutrition during their 2011 and 2012 Ramadan fasts by serving them a total of 1,000 to 1,500 calories per day.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants’ motion for summary judgment, reasoning that there was no clearly established federal law that entitled the plaintiffs to the 2,900 calories a day allegedly mandated by MDOC policy.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed this interlocutory appeal, arguing that they are entitled to qualified immunity on the plaintiffs’ Eighth Amendment claim, that the district court defined the constitutional issue too generally, and that there is no law dictating the number of calories that a prisoner must have per day during a thirty-day period.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to this district on April 4, 2013 and the defendants moved to dismiss the complaint with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The court granted their motion, concluding that the plaintiffs could only obtain adequate nutrition by violating their religious beliefs.

gold_sents: On May 21, 2012, a Native American prisoner incarcerated at the McConnell Unit of the Texas Department of Criminal Justice (TDCJ) filed this pro se federal civil rights lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]He sued multiple TDCJ employees under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]He alleged that TDJC policies that prevented his smoking a prayer pipe during Native American pipe ceremonies, limited his ability to wear a religiously significant medicine bag, and prevented him from growing long hair violated his rights under RLUIPA and the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]He sought declaratory, injunctive, and monetary relief as well as attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]An additional Native American prisoner plaintiff joined the suit shortly after filing.[SENTMARKER]In February 2013, the plaintiffs amended their complaint, consented to proceedings before a Magistrate Judge, and voluntarily dismissed all of their claims except their three RLUIPA challenges against the TDCJ Director in his official capacity and their First Amendment claim seeking damages against the Program Analyst in his individual capacity.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed cross motions for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]On February 27, 2014, the defendant’s motion for summary judgment was granted and a final judgment entered in their favor.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed to the Fifth Circuit and were successful in getting judgement on the RLUIPA grooming policy claim vacated and remanded.[SENTMARKER]On remand, the defendant’s motion for summary judgment on the RLUIPA grooming claim was denied.[SENTMARKER]As the RLUIPA grooming policy claim moved towards trial, the initial prisoner plaintiff in the case was released and his claims were dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The Court ordered the consolidation of cases Casey v. Davis (2:14-cv-13) and Cobb v. Morris (2:14-cv-22) with this case, as the two cases also were brought by Native American prisoner incarcerated at the McConnell Unit and involved RLUIPA grooming policy claims moving towards trial.[SENTMARKER]After a bench trial, Judge Ramos granted plaintiffs’ request for injunctive relief permitting them to grow their hair long, consistent with their Native American religious beliefs and entered a final judgment on February 26, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The defendant appealed, but moved to dismiss the appeal shortly after.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit granted the motion to dismiss the appeal on July 9, 2019.[SENTMARKER]This case is closed.

gold_sents: On August 31, 2020, Judge Rebecca Beach Smith in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia approved a settlement between the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) Civil Rights Division and Hampton Roads Regional Jail Authority.[SENTMARKER]The agreement resolved the DOJ’s claims alleging unlawful conditions at the Hampton Roads Regional Jail (HRRJ) in violation of CRIPA and the ADA.[SENTMARKER]Under the agreement, HRRJ will develop and implement policies, procedures, and training regarding adequate medical and mental health care and appropriate housing for prisoners with serious mental illness.[SENTMARKER]These measures include specialized mental health housing units, increased training for medical, mental health, and security personnel, proper screening and assessment for medical and mental health concerns, adequate treatment planning and suicide prevention measures, and a quality assurance program.[SENTMARKER]Per the agreement, the parties jointly appointed a monitor to assess and assist with compliance with the agreement.[SENTMARKER]HRRJ must come into substantial compliance with the agreement within five years.[SENTMARKER]The agreement can be terminated by court order.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 20, 2020, the United States of America filed a civil rights suit in the Eastern district of Virginia against the Hampton Roads regional jail authority (HRRJ) alleging that the jail violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the Constitution by failing to provide adequate medical and mental health care to prisoners and its placement of prisoners with serious mental illness in restrictive housing for prolonged periods of time.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged violations of Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA).[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into an agreement on August 20, 2020 to resolve the case without litigation.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the following terms: All new or revised policies and procedures that were created to align with this agreement will be fully implemented within six months.[SENTMARKER]The jail will provide constitutionally adequate medical care and access to services, programs, and activities to prisoners with mental health disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The United States will monitor the jail's compliance with the agreement.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On August 5, 2020, the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia entered an agreement with the Hampton Roads Regional Jail Authority (HRRJ) to improve the medical and mental health care that prisoners with serious mental illness receive at HRRJ.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into this agreement after the United States initiated an investigation pursuant to the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA) and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) in 2016.[SENTMARKER]The parties are committed to remedying the conditions identified in the CRIPA Notice and achieving compliance with Title II of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the agreement, HRRJ will provide constitutionally adequate medical care, develop and implement treatment plans that address serious medical needs in a timely manner, collaborate with mental health staff, and increase medical staffing.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the parties agreed to create a temporary mental health release award program for prisoners with severe mental illness.

gold_sents: This class-action lawsuit was filed on June 28, 2020 in response to Portland Police Bureau's allegedly illegal tactics in quelling the protests in that city after the police killing of George Floyd in May of 2020.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, who were members of media and legal observers of the protests, argued that their First Amendment and Fourth Amendment rights were violated by the PPB's use of pepper spray and rubber bullets, among other weapons.[SENTMARKER]They sought injunctive, declaratory, and monetary relief.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a TRO against the city, prohibiting the police from arresting or seizing the equipment of reporters or legal observers of the protests.[SENTMARKER]The court later granted a preliminary injunction against the city.[SENTMARKER]By July 16, President Trump had sent in federal officers from the DHS and USMS as reinforcement.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs added those two organizations as defendants and filed a motion for a TRO and preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The motion for temporary restraining order and the motion for preliminary injunction were both granted.[SENTMARKER]These decisions were appealed to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, which has yet to rule on them.[SENTMARKER]However, on October 9, the Ninth Circut declined to stay the preliminary injunction pending appeal.[SENTMARKER]The federal defendants filed a motion to dismiss, which remains pending.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing as of December 31, 2020.

pegasus_output_sents: On June 1, 2020, people from Pittsburgh and surrounding communities gathered in the East Liberty neighborhood of the City of Pittsburgh to add their voices to these nationwide protests and seek change locally.[SENTMARKER]The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police responded by escalating a peaceful protest into a scene of pandemonium, panic, violence and bloodshed.[SENTMARKER]The PBP deployed hundreds of officers to counter approximately 150 protesters.[SENTMARKER]Following some reports of property damage, PBP officers used chemical gas, rubber bullets and other projectiles, pepper spray, flashbang grenades and other riot control agents indiscriminately against everyone present, including peaceful protesters and nonviolent bystanders.[SENTMARKER]The Protesters were arrested 46 people at the protests for "failure to disperse" and were seriously injured.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed a class action suit against the defendants, alleging that they violated their First Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The class action was granted by the district court under the provisions of Rule 23(b)(2), which reads: "An action may be maintained as a group action if the prerequisites of subdivision (a) are satisfied, and in addition: (2) the party opposing the class has acted or refused to act on grounds generally applicable to the class, thereby making appropriate final injunctive relief or corresponding declaratory relief with respect to the group as a whole..."

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On September 28, 2006, the Central Falls High School soccer team played an away game at Coventry High School in Rhode Island.[SENTMARKER]Before the game began, five or six Central Falls players used the bathrooms located inside the Coventry boys locker room.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed suit in April 2008 against the Town of Coventry and several individual Coventry police officers under 42 U.S.C.  1983 ( 1983) and Rhode Island state law.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment for the defendants on all counts, holding that the officers were entitled to qualified immunity with respect to the Fourth Amendment and state privacy claims because it was not unreasonable for the officers to believe that Coach Marchand had power to consent to the search, and (2) Marchand did not vitiate the coach's consent.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On September 2018, the American Civil Liberties Union of Tennessee (ACLU-TN) sued the City of Memphis, Tennessee in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee, alleging that the City violated the First Amendment rights of Memphis residents by collecting personal information about them for the purpose of First Amendment-related intelligence in the course of a lawful investigation of criminal conduct.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree, which prohibited the Defendant from interfering with any person's right to free speech.[SENTMARKER]The Court found that the Defendant violated the clear terms of the consent decree by collecting information related to the right to freedom of speech.[SENTMARKER]On December 20, 2018, the parties filed a joint motion to stay and/or modify the decree, and the Court granted the City's motion.[SENTMARKER]On January 2, 2019, the parties entered a final judgment in favor of the City.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment required the defendants to comply with the decree.

gold_sents: In March 2004, the Department of Justice (DOJ) opened an investigation into the Virgin Islands Police Department's (VIPD) practices regarding use of excessive force, and on December 23, 2008, filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of the Virgin Islands.[SENTMARKER]On March 24, 2009, the parties signed a consent decree, detailing specific actions to be taken by VIPD.[SENTMARKER]Enforcement of the consent decree is in progress.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 23, 2009, the U.S. District Court for the District of the Virgin Islands entered a consent decree (the "Conviction Decree") in order to correct an alleged systematic violation of constitutional rights through excessive force by the Virgin Island Police Department.[SENTMARKER]The Consent Decree was the result of a cooperative effort that evinced a commitment to constitutional policing on the part of the United States Department of Justice, the Territory ofthe Virgin Islands, and the VIPD.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to implement measures of lawful, constitutional uses of force to be the cornerstone of the measures and assessment package.[SENTMARKER]The deadline for substantial compliance was March 23, 2012, to be followed by two consecutive years of compliance, at which time the Consent Decree would terminate.[SENTMARKER]In the third quarter of 2013, the Office of the Independent Monitor ("OIM" or the "Monitor"), which was established in January 2010, issued its third quarterly report detailing compliance with the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The Monitor was required to issue quarterly written, public reports detailing the Territory's compliance with and implementation of each substantive provision of the consent Decree.[SENTMARKER]The final settlement of Consent Decree compliance can only be justified by demonstrating that constitutional behaviors and practices are in place and have been sustained for two years.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In March 2004, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) initiated an investigation of an alleged pattern or practice of excessive force by the Virgin Islands Police Department (VIPD) under the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 (VCCE).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that VIPD officers used excessive force against a potential wanted subject at a bar, and transported him to his home to retrieve his ID.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that the complaint was incomplete because the officers never filed the required Form.[SENTMARKER]The District Court of the Virgin Island issued two principal orders that required the VIPD to comply with the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is the result of a cooperative effort that evinced a commitment to constitutional policing on the part of the DOJ and the Territory.[SENTMARKER]The OIM will track how VIPD implements these recommendations and will audit the compliance of sworn personnel and applicable civilian employees.

gold_sents: A group of Orthodox Jewish synagogues brought this lawsuit against the Governor of New York on October 8, 2020, alleging that the governor's restrictions on gatherings in light of surges in COVID-19 cases violated the Free Exercise Clause.[SENTMARKER]After the district court denied plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, they appealed to the Second Circuit and the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court granted the injunction in part to block the enforcement of the executive order's attendance caps pending the outcome of the appeal in the Second Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On March 23, 2020, New York Governor Andrew Cuomo issued Executive Order 202.10, which banned non-essential gatherings of any size for any reason at houses of worship in New York City.[SENTMARKER]On October 8, 2020, a group of Orthodox Jewish organizations, synagogues, and rabbis filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the Governor and the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the executive order violated their First Amendment rights by limiting attendance at homes of worship that fall within the "red," "orange," and "yellow" zones, particularly as Orthodox Jewish congregants get ready to celebrate three upcoming Jewish holidays.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the plaintiffs' request for a preliminary injunction, and the Supreme Court and the Ninth Circuit subsequently denied their requests for relief.[SENTMARKER]The case is now pending appeal.

HHS published a Final Rule, scheduled to go into effect on May 3, 2019, which would alter longstanding regulations governing Title X grants for family planning services.[SENTMARKER]Washington sought operate or administer more than 3,500 health centers providing family planning services to more than 3.7 million patients each year), a Washington-based NFPRHA member organization, and two health care professionals, challenging the same HHS Rule on behalf of themselves and their patients.[SENTMARKER]Washington and the NFPRHA parties filed preliminary injunctions on March 22, 2019, seeking to prohibit HHS from implementing the Final Rule.[SENTMARKER]Judge Bastian granted plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction, enjoining the Final Rule nationwide until further order of the court.[SENTMARKER]On May 3, 2019, defendants filed a notice of appeal and motion to stay the preliminary injunction, as well as a notice of interlocutory and preliminary injunction appeal regarding plaintiffs’ preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]On June 20, 2019, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals issued a three-judge panel per curiam decision granting defendant’s motion to stay pending appeal.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit noted that the Final Rule was challenged in federal court in California, Oregon, and Washington (this case), and district courts in each case granted plaintiffs’ Circuit.[SENTMARKER]On July 11, 2019, the Ninth Circuit en banc court denied the motions for administrative stay of the three-judge panel’s order granting defendant’s motion to stay pending injunction orders pending consideration of the appeals on the merits.[SENTMARKER]This case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: In April 2019, a group of state governments and existing Title X grantees challenged the Department of Health and Human Services' (HHS) new regulations in federal court in three states (California, Washington, and Oregon) and sought preliminary injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The district courts granted plaintiffs’ preliminary injunction motions on nearly identical grounds.[SENTMARKER]The court held that plaintiffs would not prevail on the merits of their legal claims, and they were not entitled to the extraordinary remedy of a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]In light of HHS’s reasoned explanation of its decisions and its consideration of the comments raised, the court rejected plaintiffs’ arguments that HHS failed to base its decision on evidence, failed to consider potential harms in its cost-benefit analysis, and failed to explain its reasons for departing from the 2000 Rule.

gold_sents: In 1964, a group of African American families filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the defendant Jefferson Parish School Board had violated their rights under the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by continuing to segregate the school system.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted injunctive relief, mandated desegregation of the school system, and required that the defendants use busing to speed up the integration process.[SENTMARKER]The injunction remained in place for several decades.[SENTMARKER]In 2007, the School Board sought to implement a magnet school program in the hopes of boosting academics and increasing school diversity.[SENTMARKER]The parties jointly moved to supplement the desegregation plan to include the magnet school program, and the Court issued Consent Orders in 2008-2009 that enabled the School Board's plans.[SENTMARKER]However, issues arose in the following years with the School Board's implementation of the plan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that the defendants were using the Consent Orders as a pretext to conceal attempts to continue a system of racially segregated schools.[SENTMARKER]After the Consent Orders expired, the parties reached a settlement agreement and the Court declared Jefferson Parish Schools unitary in 2011.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 30, 1964, the Jefferson Parish School Board (JPSB) filed this civil rights suit in the United States District Court for the Eastern district of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The suit sought to desegregate the public schools of Jefferson Parish and to eliminate the vestiges of the prior dual school system.[SENTMARKER]In August 1971, the court ordered the JPSB to implement, beginning on August 31, 1971, the plan for desegregation of the public school of the parish which had been submitted to the court eight days earlier.[SENTMARKER]On May 15, 2008, the court approved numerous unopposed modifications of the previously operative orders covering all phases of school district operation.[SENTMARKER]The JPSB then filed a motion for modification of the order, which was denied by the court.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on June 30, 2011 and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On August 10, 1971, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern district of Louisiana against the Jefferson Parish School Board and the school superintendent for maintaining and operating a compulsory bi-racial school system in Jefferson Parish, Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the school system was in violation of the Consent Order and the Constitution by failing to adequately desegregate its school system to the extent possible.[SENTMARKER]The district court approved the school board's desegregation plan in 1971 and the plaintiffs filed a joint motion in 2007 to supplement the desegregation plan.[SENTMARKER]In 2007, the district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a supplement to the consent order.[SENTMARKER]The parties jointly presented to the court a motion listing suggested modifications to existing orders.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the motion and entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: On Dec.[SENTMARKER]3, 1997, Barbara Grutter brought this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the University of Michigan Law School.[SENTMARKER]She claimed that, in denying her admission, the school discriminated against her on the basis of her race, and violated the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The case made its way to the Supreme Court, which held that the law school's desire to obtain a "critical mass" of underrepresented minority students counted as a narrowly tailored use of race in its admissions process and was not unconstitutional.
pegasus_output_sents: In December 1997, a white female law student filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern district of Michigan alleging that the law school's admissions policy violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment and Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by using race as a factor in considering applications for admission.[SENTMARKER]In March 2001, the court granted the plaintiffs' request for declaratory relief and enjoined the Law School from using race to further its interest in achieving a diverse student body.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Court of Appeals for the 6th Circuit reversed the district court's judgment and vacated the injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2011 voters in Wisconsin filed this lawsuit in the US District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that their fundamental right to vote had been violated by Act 23, Wisconsin's law implementing a voter ID requirement.[SENTMARKER]After much litigation, in 2016 a judge granted a preliminary injunction allowing voters without IDs to sign an affidavit in place of the ID requirement for the 2016 presidential election.[SENTMARKER]The state appealed the injunction to the Seventh Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Seventh Circuit stayed the injunction pending the appeal.[SENTMARKER]As of December 2019, the appeal remained pending in the Seventh Circuit.

pegasus_output_sents: On May 12, 2020, a group of individuals with disabilities filed a lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]district court in New York against Governor Andrew Cuomo for failing to provide a simultaneous American Sign Language (ASL) interpreter for television broadcast during his daily press briefings regarding the COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the county violated the ADA and Rehab Act, as well as the Minnesota Human Rights Act, because there was no ASL interpreter at some of the meetings, and at other meetings the ASL interpretation was "imperfect" because the interpreter spent time interpreting individual discussions instead of interpreting the large-group discussion.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction on May 12, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The Eighth Circuit affirmed the district court's grant of summary judgment for the county, holding in part that the ADA did not require the county to provide an ASL interpreter at every meeting because based on the interpretation services that were provided the county "effectively communicated" the relevant information to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On July 16, 2019, the East Bay Sanctuary Covenant, Al Otro Lado, Innovation Law Lab, and the Central American Resource Center in Los Angeles brought this suit against the U.S. Attorney General and  Secretary of Homeland Security.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs challenged the federal immigration rule restricting eligibility for asylum for noncitizens who transited through another country prior to reaching the southern U.S. border.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs claimed the rule violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs successfully sought a preliminary nationwide injunction.[SENTMARKER]However, defendants appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit and the nationwide scope of the injunction was stayed.[SENTMARKER]Then the District Court restored the nationwide scope of the injunction on September 9, 2019, but the government again appealed and the U.S. Supreme Court granted a stay pending disposition of the appeal in the 9th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The District Court issued a separate preliminary injunction against another rule issued by the Department of Homeland Security in the closing days of the Trump Administration which was substantially similar to the one already enjoined.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit upheld the original injunction in April, 2021.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing but is likely to terminate soon given the change in presidential administrations.

gold_sents: This is a class action lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of a South Carolina immigration law which requires state and local law enforcement officers to investigate the immigration status of any individual they stop, detain, or arrest whenever they have a "reasonable suspicion" that the individual lacks immigration status, allows law enforcement officers to arrest individuals solely for failing to carry registration documents, makes it a crime to harbor or transport an undocumented immigrant or to be harbored or transported by others if one is an undocumented immigrant, and imposes civil liability on the police for failing to enforce its provisions to the maximum extent possible.[SENTMARKER]The law was patterned after Arizona's SB 1070.[SENTMARKER]The District Court has issued a preliminary injunction barring enforcement of the law, and this injunction has been appealed to the Fourth Circuit; in the meantime, the case, along with several others like it from different states, are stayed at the District Court or U.S.[SENTMARKER]Appellate level pending the decision of the Supreme Court in United States v. United States was decided the issue was remanded to the District Court.[SENTMARKER]The district court left in place most of its original preliminary injunction, enjoining the state from enforcing Sections 4, 5, and 6 (B)(2).[SENTMARKER]The 4th Circuit per Judge Davis agreed and affirmed the order on July 13, 2013.[SENTMARKER]In March of 2014 Judge Gergel permanently enjoined South Carolina from enforcing Sections 4, 5, and 6(B)(2).[SENTMARKER]Furthermore the state agreed to more favorable interpretations of Section 7, and the remainder of Section, encouraging the Plaintiffs to dismiss their claims on those sections without prejudice.

pegasus_output_sents: [ENTITYCHAIN] January 27, 2014 DATE | U.S. District Court Northern District of California ORG ||| January 27, 2015 DATE ||| Twitter, Inc.<n>On January 27, 2014, in connection with pending complaints filed with the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court by Facebook, Google, Yahoo, Microsoft, and LinkedIn, Twitter filed a lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]district court for the Northern District Of California.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that, among other things, that Twitter 28 seeks to publish a "Transparency Report" with certain data about legal process it has received pursuant to the FISA and NSL laws.[SENTMARKER]In November 2014, the court granted the government's motion for summary judgment on the grounds that the newly classified and unclassified information was not properly classified under Executive Order No. 1354 and therefore protected by the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On January 27, 2015, the government filed a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on January 27, 2015.

pegasus_output_sents: On June 3, 2014, The New York Times Company and reporter Charlie Savage filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) suit against the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, on March 12, 2014, Mr. Savage submitted a FOIA request to the DOJ seeking certain documents regarding the warrantless surveillance program known as "Electronic Surveillance and Physical Search of Terrorist Groups, Their Agents, and Related Targets" ( FISC).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the DOJ's failure to produce responsive documents violated the FOIA.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice on October 28, 2015, without costs or attorneys' fees.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: This is an action under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) against the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) and its constituent part, the National Security Division (NSD) for the production of documents related to the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court (FISC) and the warrantless surveillance program.[SENTMARKER]In 1978, Congress enacted the FISA to govern the procedures for electronic surveillance conducted by the government for national security purposes.[SENTMARKER]The statute created the FISC, whose members would be unilaterally selected by the Chief Justice from the ranks of Article III judges to serve staggered, seven-year terms.[SENTMARKER]However, many crucial documents relating to FISC remain secret.[SENTMARKER]On March 12, 2014, Plaintiff Charlie Savage submitted a FOIA request (the "Request") to DOJ seeking certain materials pertaining to the foreign intelligence surveillance court.[SENTMARKER]The Request sought "all government motions and briefs, judicial orders, and memorandum opinions" concerning the following FISC litigation: 1) The July 22, 2002 case, "In Rereferenced Electronic Surveillance and Physical Search oflnternational Terrorist Groups, Their Agents, and Related Targets" 2) The "Raw Take" sharing order (3) The January 10, 2007 orders bringing the warrantfree surveillance program under FISC authority whose existence was disclosed by Attorney General Alberto Gonzales in his Jan.[SENTMARKER]3, 2007 opinion.[SENTMARKER]The requested documents were responsive to categories 3 through 6 of the request.[SENTMARKER]Information has been redacted from these documents pursuant to the FOIA exemption or exemptions.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment, and the case was closed.

gold_sents: On January 20, 2010, an employee of the federal judiciary married to her same-sex partner under California law filed a lawsuit against the federal Office of Personnel Management (OPM) in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California, San Francisco Division, alleging that the federal Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) violates the Fifth Amendment by refusing to recognize lawful same-sex marriages for purposes of the laws governing spousal health benefits for federal employees, thereby denying her of a benefit that would be available to her if her spouse were of the opposite sex.[SENTMARKER]On February 22, 2012, the District Court granted summary judgment to the plaintiff, holding that the application of DOMA to deny spousal health benefits in this case did not have a rational basis and thus constituted a Fifth Amendment violation.[SENTMARKER]It entered a permanent injunction prohibiting the defendants from interfering with the enrollment of the plaintiff's wife in her family health benefits plan.[SENTMARKER]On July 3, 2012, the U.S. Department of Justice filed a petition in the Supreme Court for certiorari prior to judgment.[SENTMARKER]That petition was held without decision while the Court considered the California Prop.[SENTMARKER]8 case (PB-CA-0029 in this Clearinghouse) and Windsor, the DOMA case from the Second Circuit (PB-NY-0017 in this Clearinghouse), in which the Court granted review on December 7.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed following the decision in Windsor holding § 3 of DOMA unconstitutional.

gold_sents: The Disability Rights Network (DRN), a Pennsylvania non-profit, filed this Eighth Amendment suit against the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections (PDOC) for the PDOC's use of solitary confinement with severely mentally ill prisoners.[SENTMARKER]On January 5, 2015, the parties executed a settlement agreement for dismissal of the matter, in which the PDOC agreed to implement certain improvements and to pay $750,000 to DRN.[SENTMARKER]In particular, the PDOC will evaluate all incoming prisoners for serious mental illness, and will place prisoners with serious mental illness in solitary confinement only in "exceptional" circumstances; even then, a prisoner with serious mental illness can be kept in solitary confinement for no longer than 30 days and must be allowed out of their cells for 20 hours per week.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also provided for a monitor to report on compliance, and will remain in effect for 3 years (less if the defendant demonstrates substantial compliance for a period of 18 months).[SENTMARKER]There has been no activity on the docket since May 2015 and the case is presumably closed since the three year time period set in the agreement has lapsed.

gold_sents: In July 2008, the plaintiffs sued the City of Tenaha under the Fourth Amendment (unreasonable search and seizure) and the Fourteenth Amendment (equal protection).[SENTMARKER]They claimed that law enforcement officials in and around the City of Tenaha have developed an illegal practice of targeting, stopping, detaining, searching, and often seizing property from people who appeared to be non-white or who were traveling with non-white passengers.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that they had been victims of such stops and seizures of amounts up to $50,000, as well as false prosecution or detention.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a preliminary settlement in August 2012.[SENTMARKER]Their proposed consent decree included: video and audio recordings of all stops; written documentation with details of the stop; no more dog searches in routine traffic stops; written and oral consent for a search; all asset forfeiture revenue must be donated to nonprofits or used for audio/video equipment or training; and use of an impartial monitor.[SENTMARKER]The court approved the consent decree, which it later extended to early 2021 after the plaintiffs alleged noncompliance by the City.

gold_sents: In early 2011, an electronic communication service provider that had received a National Security Letter (NSL) from the federal government filed a petition to set aside the NSL in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The recipient asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief, claiming that a nondisclosure provision of the NSL Statute, 18 U.S.C. § 2709, violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On March 14, 2013, U.S. District Judge Susan Illston granted the petition to set aside the NSL, declaring that § 2709 violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The government was therefore enjoined from issuing NSLs under § 2709 or from enforcing the nondisclosure provision in this or any other case.[SENTMARKER]The government appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit, but while the appeal was pending, Congress amended § 2709 and 18 U.S.C. § 3511 as part of the USA FREEDOM Act of 2015.[SENTMARKER]The district court and Ninth Circuit upheld the constitutionality of the revised § 2709 and § 3511.[SENTMARKER]But the district court held that the government failed to justify nondisclosure in one case involving the recipient, and the government found that nondisclosure was no longer required in another case involving the recipient.[SENTMARKER]As a result, the recipient could reveal itself as CREDO Mobile.

gold_sents: This class action was about whether the City of New York improperly denied federally sponsored cash assistance to qualified New York City residents under a program implemented by the city in the late 1990s.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs each claimed to be qualified welfare beneficiaries who had been improperly denied assistance by one of New York City’s new job centers in violation of the fourteenth amendment guarantee of due process, the city’s obligations under 7 U.S.C. §2020 (the Supplemental Nutritional Assistance Program—then referred to as Food Stamps) and 42 U.S.C. §1396 (Medicaid), in addition to violating state law; the plaintiffs sought class certification for all similarly situated New York City residents, as well as declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York on December 16, 1998, with Judge William H. Pauley presiding.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a temporary restraining order on the same day directing the city to provide emergency food stamps and cash assistance to the named plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction in-part to the plaintiffs on January 21, 1999.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered the city to (1) allow applicants for public assistance to apply for benefits the first day they visit a job center, (2) cease conversion of income support centers to job centers without a formal hearing, (3) make eligibility requirements for food stamps and Medicaid separately from the eligibility determination from cash assistance, (4) send applicants timely notice of the city’s decision on whether they qualify for benefits, and (5) form a corrective plan for achieving its policy goals while also meeting the needs of public assistance applicants.[SENTMARKER]The city moved to vacate the preliminary injunction on December 10, 1999, after procuring more evidence surrounding the efficacy of the job centers in achieving their welfare obligations.[SENTMARKER]Meanwhile, the State of New York moved to dismiss the complaint against them for failure to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]Judge Pauley denied both motions and granted the plaintiff’s motion for class certification on July 21, 2000.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a permanent injunction in favor of the plaintiffs on December 30, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The permanent injunction directed both the city and state to: (i) provide expedited food stamp service to eligible applications within 7 days; .[SENTMARKER](ii) separately process applications for food stamps when the applications for cash assistance are denied or withdrawn; .[SENTMARKER](iii) send notices to applicants confirming voluntary withdrawals for Medicaid in accord with 42 C.F.R. 435.913 and document such withdrawals pursuant to 7 C.F.R. 273.2(c)(6); and (iv) provide adequate and timely notice by correctly completing certain documentation.[SENTMARKER]The injunction also required the state to supervise the city and make sure it met the obligations of the injunction.[SENTMARKER]On January 13, 2005, the plaintiffs moved for reconsideration of the part of the December order in which the court concluded that 8 N.Y.C.R.R.[SENTMARKER]§ 387.8(a)(2)(i)(a) did not confer a privately enforceable right of action and that plaintiffs’ claim under New York Social Services Law § 133 was barred by the doctrine of sovereign immunity.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the motion on February 14, 2005.[SENTMARKER]Final judgement was entered on December 14, 2005; the court also granted the plaintiffs declaratory judgment.[SENTMARKER]Both the state and the city appealed the permanent injunction to the Second Circuit on January 12, 2006, but the city dropped its appeal.[SENTMARKER]On October 31, 2007, the Second Circuit reversed the district court, ruling that the state did not have a non-delegable duty to administer the decentralized Medicaid and Food Stamp programs, the state’s efforts in supervising the city since the permanent injunction was issued were adequate, and the district court exceeded its authority by issuing a permanent injunction in light of New York State’s affirmative supervisory steps it had taken to assure compliance.[SENTMARKER]In a series of stipulations and orders from January 31, 2007 to July 22, 2011, the City of New York agreed to pay a total of $2,920,675.94 to plaintiffs for attorney fees and costs sought; the state agreed to pay a further $639,918.98.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This case was filed by a trans woman incarcerated in a men's prison in Washington State on September 5, 2017 in the District Court for the Western District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]She alleges that the blanket policy in the Washington Department of Correction denying prisoners access to gender affirming surgery amounts to a violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]She is represented by the ACLU, and is seeking injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties came to a preliminary settlement agreement on March 20, 2020, and proceedings were stayed for 180 days in an attempt to implement the agreement.
